element.name: 31 A Walk in the Garden-Djouce by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (1/3.5)
element.long-description:
Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE
Still south I went and west and south again,
Through Wicklow from the morning till the night,
And far from cities, and the sights of men,
Lived with the sunshine, and the moon’s delight.
I knew the stars, the flowers, and the birds,
The grey and wintry sides of many glens,
And did but half remember human words,
In converse with the mountains, moors, and fens.
(John Millington Synge)
This is a very simple multi on one of the most popular hiking mountains in Wicklow. It can be accessed from many directions including Maulin and War Hill as indicated on the map above where I have shown a good 4 hour hike in a circular fashion during which a geocacher could pick up a number of super caches. The only stage indicated on this illustration refers to this cache..
Djouce can also be accessed from the JB Malone side as well as an up and down hike from Crone car park without the circular route.
There was a cache here up to recently but it has now been archived by Donnacha and he has kindly given me permission to replace it with this one
No matter which way you choose to do this cache, I would recommend that you take the stroll of about 800 metres down, in the general direction of War Hill to visit The Coffin Stone where I have placed another cache. The stone is quite impressive and apparently some bones were found beneath which indicated that it was a Megalithic Portal Tomb. Amazing to think that such a place existed in the distant past in such remote surroundings though the presence of plenty of deer may help to explain that.
For this cache you need to find Stage 1 which is very close to the summit of Djouce. This is the only stage required to find the coordinates for the cache. Call the date in the month that you see "A" and call the age given "BC".
The cache is not far away at N53 07.(ABC X 2) -69 W006 14.ABC - 85.
From Mountain Views:
Djouce Mountain Wicklow County Dioghais A name in Irish (Ir. Dioghais [GE], 'fortified height') Height: 725 metres OS 1/50k Mapsheet: 56 for top Grid Ref: O17858 10364 Latitude: 53.131066 Longitude: -6.239936 ITM: 717781 710395 Prominence: 200m Isolation: 1.4km Rating graphic. Djouce dominates the views of the Wicklow Mountains from Roundwood and Newtown Mountkennedy. The Old Irish word dígas is defined by the Dictionary of the Irish Language as 'high, lofty; a height'. There is a Sliab Digsa mentioned in the Metrical Dindshenchas, where the second element is interpreted as a woman's name. This shows that the meaning of dígas was already obscure by the time of the Metrical Dindshenchas (12th century) and a story was probably invented to account for the name. Djouce is the 91st highest summit in Ireland. Our data has reached 100% of the goal for this summit. (Details)
Do not start the trek without all the proper mountain rain gear, waterproof boots and the guidance material, compass, map, GPSr with mapping etc.
Please note that all parts of this cache are hiked at your own risk. The cache owner takes no responsibility of any sort for any reason including accidents or mishaps.
Please be aware that cars parked in areas close to walking trails are vulnerable and they can be vandalised or stolen. Unfortunately this is an ongoing problem which is extremely difficult to solve, so there is a risk involved.
Please observe the country code to the best of your ability. Local landowners often generously allow access to upland areas across or through parts of their private property. Please, please be conscious of this and return the courtesy by keeping all gates closed, immediately and not on your way back!. Please use the gates where appropriate but if you have to climb over them then use the hinged side ONLY.
Please do not cause any damage of any sort to fences or barriers along the way.

ul.li:
2010-06-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by daraconn
My 3rd and last WITG cache of the day. A short easy walk up from the Coffin Stone to the summit. Unusually there were sheep right at the summit, grazing around the rocky outcrop at the trig point. They had all been shorn and were painted red all over. Lovely enjoyable cache, then the long walk back down to the car. Thanks for yet another enjoyable and well-planned walk in the garden!

2010-05-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by didi2206
Super day & super cache... Thanks!!

2010-05-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
Found with Shailaja on a windy & cloudy day at the summit. No views at all. About a dozen guys from the Army were there having a lunch break. I wouldn't like to have been carrying the load they had on their backs. TFTC Toffee Man #347.

2010-05-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by Shailaja
Found on a hike with Toffee Man. Nice little Multi, took two attempts to get the maths right - good thing Toffee Man was looking over my shoulder ;) Windy up top and we were a few minutes wandering around with conflicting coords until I spotted some stones and went digging! Very well hidden and I made sure I left it the same way. TFTC Shailaja

2010-05-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by theswerve
Nice short multi to finish a long day in the hills...quickly found...back to the car...TFTC...

wpt.name: GC26PK2
wpt.desc: 31 A Walk in the Garden-Djouce by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (1/3.5)

Additional Waypoints

Unusually there were sheep right at the summit, grazing around the rocky outcrop at the trig point. They had all been shorn and were painted red all over. Very well hidden and I made sure I left it the same way. TFTC Shailaja
Nice short multi to finish a long day in the hills...quickly found...back to the car...TFTC...
